issue.title: talosctl shutdown doesn't error if no talosconfig is passed.
issue.body:
## Bug Report

I ended up in a terminal where I hadn't exported `TALOSCONFIG` and issued a `talosctl shutdown` command and nothing happened.  I assumed it was an async command and waited... and waited.

### Description

There should be an error message if you issue a `talosctl shutdown` command without either an explicit `--talosconfig` or a `TALOSCONFIG` env var.

### Logs

```
/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
> unset TALOSCONFIG

/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
> talosctl shutdown -n 192.168.1.206 -e 192.168.1.206 --force

/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
```
(no output seen on shutdown command)

### Environment

- Talos version: [`talosctl version --nodes <problematic nodes>`] 1.5.4
- Kubernetes version: [`kubectl version --short`] v1.28.2
- Platform: metal-pine64

comment.body: @smira Yes, seems like it. I'll submit a fix.

issue.title: talosctl shutdown doesn't error if no talosconfig is passed.
issue.body:
## Bug Report

I ended up in a terminal where I hadn't exported `TALOSCONFIG` and issued a `talosctl shutdown` command and nothing happened.  I assumed it was an async command and waited... and waited.

### Description

There should be an error message if you issue a `talosctl shutdown` command without either an explicit `--talosconfig` or a `TALOSCONFIG` env var.

### Logs

```
/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
> unset TALOSCONFIG

/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
> talosctl shutdown -n 192.168.1.206 -e 192.168.1.206 --force

/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
```
(no output seen on shutdown command)

### Environment

- Talos version: [`talosctl version --nodes <problematic nodes>`] 1.5.4
- Kubernetes version: [`kubectl version --short`] v1.28.2
- Platform: metal-pine64

comment.body:
No, I don't, and this is still an error that the CLI should handle, no matter what the cause!

```
/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [13:38]
> talosctl config info
no context is set

/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [13:38]
> talosctl shutdown -n 192.168.1.206 -e 192.168.1.206 --force

/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [13:39]
>
```
This is actually an issue in the CLI - no context should always return an error, not silently fail!

Please reopen.

issue.title: Removing then adding a new control plane node : service "etcd" to be "up"
issue.body:
## Bug Report
I need to change networks for my control plane nodes so i follow the documentation : https://www.talos.dev/v1.3/learn-more/control-plane/
Scaling down then scaling up the control plane.

The hostname doesn't change (km13-url-pp), just the IP (old : 10.31.224.10, new : 10.31.193.102).

```
$ talosctl -e 10.31.192.10 -n 10.31.224.10 --talosconfig talosconfig reset
$ kubectl delete no km13-url-pp
```

The node was removed from the kubernetes cluster.

Then i build the new VM, same hostname, new IP. I injected the new machine configuration.
I powered it on.

### Description
The node was added in the etcd cluster.
```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.192.10 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig etcd members
NODE           ID                 HOSTNAME      PEER URLS                    CLIENT URLS                  LEARNER
10.31.192.10   744eedebce0e8271   km11-url-pp   https://10.31.192.10:2380    https://10.31.192.10:2379    false
10.31.192.10   e80d8668a1a51c89   km12-url-pp   https://10.31.208.10:2380    https://10.31.208.10:2379    false
10.31.192.10   f40b64b37065098b   km13-url-pp   https://10.31.193.102:2380   https://10.31.193.102:2379   true
```

But the etcd service is not healthy.
```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.193.102 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig services
NODE            SERVICE      STATE     HEALTH   LAST CHANGE   LAST EVENT
10.31.193.102   apid         Running   OK       35m32s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   containerd   Running   OK       35m38s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   cri          Running   OK       35m37s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   etcd         Running   Fail     35m23s ago    Health check failed: error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded
10.31.193.102   kubelet      Running   OK       35m27s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   machined     Running   OK       35m39s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   trustd       Running   OK       35m37s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   udevd        Running   OK       35m38s ago    Health check successful
```

```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.193.102 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig services etcd
NODE                  10.31.193.102
ID                    etcd
STATE                 Running
HEALTH                Fail
LAST HEALTH MESSAGE   error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded
EVENTS                [Running]: Health check failed: error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded (35m43s ago)
                      [Running]: Started task etcd (PID 2389) for container etcd (35m52s ago)
                      [Preparing]: Creating service runner (35m53s ago)
                      [Preparing]: Running pre state (35m56s ago)
                      [Waiting]: Waiting for service "cri" to be "up" (35m56s ago)
                      [Waiting]: Waiting for service "cri" to be "up", time sync, network, etcd spec (35m57s ago)
```
The new control node can't be added to the cluster.

I might forget or did something wrong but i dont't know what.
### Logs
In the dmesg of the node
`10.31.193.102: user: warning: [2023-10-26T09:52:56.683171256Z]: [talos] task startAllServices (1/1): service "etcd" to be "up"`

### Environment

- Talos version: 1.3.7
- Kubernetes version: 1.25.14
- Platform: VM control plane and bare metal workers

comment.body: `nc` doesn't report connection errors this way, fyi

issue.title: Removing then adding a new control plane node : service "etcd" to be "up"
issue.body:
## Bug Report
I need to change networks for my control plane nodes so i follow the documentation : https://www.talos.dev/v1.3/learn-more/control-plane/
Scaling down then scaling up the control plane.

The hostname doesn't change (km13-url-pp), just the IP (old : 10.31.224.10, new : 10.31.193.102).

```
$ talosctl -e 10.31.192.10 -n 10.31.224.10 --talosconfig talosconfig reset
$ kubectl delete no km13-url-pp
```

The node was removed from the kubernetes cluster.

Then i build the new VM, same hostname, new IP. I injected the new machine configuration.
I powered it on.

### Description
The node was added in the etcd cluster.
```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.192.10 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig etcd members
NODE           ID                 HOSTNAME      PEER URLS                    CLIENT URLS                  LEARNER
10.31.192.10   744eedebce0e8271   km11-url-pp   https://10.31.192.10:2380    https://10.31.192.10:2379    false
10.31.192.10   e80d8668a1a51c89   km12-url-pp   https://10.31.208.10:2380    https://10.31.208.10:2379    false
10.31.192.10   f40b64b37065098b   km13-url-pp   https://10.31.193.102:2380   https://10.31.193.102:2379   true
```

But the etcd service is not healthy.
```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.193.102 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig services
NODE            SERVICE      STATE     HEALTH   LAST CHANGE   LAST EVENT
10.31.193.102   apid         Running   OK       35m32s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   containerd   Running   OK       35m38s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   cri          Running   OK       35m37s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   etcd         Running   Fail     35m23s ago    Health check failed: error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded
10.31.193.102   kubelet      Running   OK       35m27s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   machined     Running   OK       35m39s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   trustd       Running   OK       35m37s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   udevd        Running   OK       35m38s ago    Health check successful
```

```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.193.102 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig services etcd
NODE                  10.31.193.102
ID                    etcd
STATE                 Running
HEALTH                Fail
LAST HEALTH MESSAGE   error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded
EVENTS                [Running]: Health check failed: error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded (35m43s ago)
                      [Running]: Started task etcd (PID 2389) for container etcd (35m52s ago)
                      [Preparing]: Creating service runner (35m53s ago)
                      [Preparing]: Running pre state (35m56s ago)
                      [Waiting]: Waiting for service "cri" to be "up" (35m56s ago)
                      [Waiting]: Waiting for service "cri" to be "up", time sync, network, etcd spec (35m57s ago)
```
The new control node can't be added to the cluster.

I might forget or did something wrong but i dont't know what.
### Logs
In the dmesg of the node
`10.31.193.102: user: warning: [2023-10-26T09:52:56.683171256Z]: [talos] task startAllServices (1/1): service "etcd" to be "up"`

### Environment

- Talos version: 1.3.7
- Kubernetes version: 1.25.14
- Platform: VM control plane and bare metal workers

comment.body:
Hello smira,

Thanks for the reply.

No firewall between networks. severals vlans in one vrf.

TCP connections between etcd are working.

A VM in the same vlan as km13-url-pp
```
# ip a
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
    inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
2: ser: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 00:50:56:b2:d6:12 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    altname enp11s0
    altname ens192
    inet 10.31.193.34/24 brd 10.31.193.255 scope global noprefixroute ser
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
```
```
# nc 10.31.192.10 2380
^C
# nc 10.31.192.10 2379
^C
# nc 10.31.208.10 2380
^C
# nc 10.31.208.10 2379
^C
# 
# nc 10.31.193.102 2380
^C
# nc 10.31.193.102 2379
^C
```
A VM in the same vlan as km11-url-pp
```
# ip a
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
    inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
2: ser: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 9000 qdisc mq state UP group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 00:50:56:8e:0e:7a brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    altname enp11s0
    altname ens192
    inet 10.31.192.201/24 brd 10.31.192.255 scope global noprefixroute ser
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
3: kubeapi1: <BROADCAST,NOARP,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 9000 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 12:ee:9b:e5:b6:cc brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    inet 10.31.240.1/32 scope global noprefixroute kubeapi1
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
```

```
# nc 10.31.192.10 2380
^C
# nc 10.31.192.10 2379
^C
]# nc 10.31.208.10 2380
^C
# nc 10.31.208.10 2379
^C
# nc 10.31.193.102 2380
^C
# nc 10.31.193.102 2379
^C
```
Same thing with a VM in the same vlan as km12-url-pp.

In the etcd log on km13-url-pp.
```
10.31.193.102: {"level":"warn","ts":"2023-10-27T07:51:13.384Z","caller":"etcdserver/server.go:2083","msg":"failed to publish local member to cluster through raft","local-member-id":"f40b64b37065098b","local-member-attributes":"{Name:km13-url-pp ClientURLs:[https://10.31.193.102:2379]}","request-path":"/0/members/f40b64b37065098b/attributes","publish-timeout":"7s","error":"etcdserver: request timed out, possibly due to connection lost"}
10.31.193.102: {"level":"warn","ts":"2023-10-27T07:51:13.455Z","caller":"rafthttp/http.go:413","msg":"failed to find remote peer in cluster","local-member-id":"f40b64b37065098b","remote-peer-id-stream-handler":"f40b64b37065098b","remote-peer-id-from":"744eedebce0e8271","cluster-id":"94f4f248b4d5ad54"}
```
In the etcd log on km11-url-pp.
```
10.31.192.10: {"level":"warn","ts":"2023-10-27T07:51:57.064Z","caller":"embed/config_logging.go:169","msg":"rejected connection","remote-addr":"10.31.193.102:57716","server-name":"","error":"tls: first record does not look like a TLS handshake"}
10.31.192.10: {"level":"warn","ts":"2023-10-27T07:51:57.151Z","caller":"rafthttp/peer_status.go:66","msg":"peer became inactive (message send to peer failed)","peer-id":"f40b64b37065098b","error":"failed to dial f40b64b37065098b on stream Message (peer f40b64b37065098b failed to find local node 744eedebce0e8271)"}
```
It seems that there is a TLS problem.
I will continue to investigate.

issue.title: Removing then adding a new control plane node : service "etcd" to be "up"
issue.body:
## Bug Report
I need to change networks for my control plane nodes so i follow the documentation : https://www.talos.dev/v1.3/learn-more/control-plane/
Scaling down then scaling up the control plane.

The hostname doesn't change (km13-url-pp), just the IP (old : 10.31.224.10, new : 10.31.193.102).

```
$ talosctl -e 10.31.192.10 -n 10.31.224.10 --talosconfig talosconfig reset
$ kubectl delete no km13-url-pp
```

The node was removed from the kubernetes cluster.

Then i build the new VM, same hostname, new IP. I injected the new machine configuration.
I powered it on.

### Description
The node was added in the etcd cluster.
```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.192.10 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig etcd members
NODE           ID                 HOSTNAME      PEER URLS                    CLIENT URLS                  LEARNER
10.31.192.10   744eedebce0e8271   km11-url-pp   https://10.31.192.10:2380    https://10.31.192.10:2379    false
10.31.192.10   e80d8668a1a51c89   km12-url-pp   https://10.31.208.10:2380    https://10.31.208.10:2379    false
10.31.192.10   f40b64b37065098b   km13-url-pp   https://10.31.193.102:2380   https://10.31.193.102:2379   true
```

But the etcd service is not healthy.
```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.193.102 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig services
NODE            SERVICE      STATE     HEALTH   LAST CHANGE   LAST EVENT
10.31.193.102   apid         Running   OK       35m32s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   containerd   Running   OK       35m38s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   cri          Running   OK       35m37s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   etcd         Running   Fail     35m23s ago    Health check failed: error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded
10.31.193.102   kubelet      Running   OK       35m27s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   machined     Running   OK       35m39s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   trustd       Running   OK       35m37s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   udevd        Running   OK       35m38s ago    Health check successful
```

```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.193.102 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig services etcd
NODE                  10.31.193.102
ID                    etcd
STATE                 Running
HEALTH                Fail
LAST HEALTH MESSAGE   error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded
EVENTS                [Running]: Health check failed: error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded (35m43s ago)
                      [Running]: Started task etcd (PID 2389) for container etcd (35m52s ago)
                      [Preparing]: Creating service runner (35m53s ago)
                      [Preparing]: Running pre state (35m56s ago)
                      [Waiting]: Waiting for service "cri" to be "up" (35m56s ago)
                      [Waiting]: Waiting for service "cri" to be "up", time sync, network, etcd spec (35m57s ago)
```
The new control node can't be added to the cluster.

I might forget or did something wrong but i dont't know what.
### Logs
In the dmesg of the node
`10.31.193.102: user: warning: [2023-10-26T09:52:56.683171256Z]: [talos] task startAllServices (1/1): service "etcd" to be "up"`

### Environment

- Talos version: 1.3.7
- Kubernetes version: 1.25.14
- Platform: VM control plane and bare metal workers

comment.body: As you can see from your output, your new member is in the `learner` state, so it tries to sync data from other replicas. You might need to look into `etcd` logs to see why it fails to, my most probable guess is the firewall somewhere in your network.

issue.title: Removing then adding a new control plane node : service "etcd" to be "up"
issue.body:
## Bug Report
I need to change networks for my control plane nodes so i follow the documentation : https://www.talos.dev/v1.3/learn-more/control-plane/
Scaling down then scaling up the control plane.

The hostname doesn't change (km13-url-pp), just the IP (old : 10.31.224.10, new : 10.31.193.102).

```
$ talosctl -e 10.31.192.10 -n 10.31.224.10 --talosconfig talosconfig reset
$ kubectl delete no km13-url-pp
```

The node was removed from the kubernetes cluster.

Then i build the new VM, same hostname, new IP. I injected the new machine configuration.
I powered it on.

### Description
The node was added in the etcd cluster.
```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.192.10 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig etcd members
NODE           ID                 HOSTNAME      PEER URLS                    CLIENT URLS                  LEARNER
10.31.192.10   744eedebce0e8271   km11-url-pp   https://10.31.192.10:2380    https://10.31.192.10:2379    false
10.31.192.10   e80d8668a1a51c89   km12-url-pp   https://10.31.208.10:2380    https://10.31.208.10:2379    false
10.31.192.10   f40b64b37065098b   km13-url-pp   https://10.31.193.102:2380   https://10.31.193.102:2379   true
```

But the etcd service is not healthy.
```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.193.102 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig services
NODE            SERVICE      STATE     HEALTH   LAST CHANGE   LAST EVENT
10.31.193.102   apid         Running   OK       35m32s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   containerd   Running   OK       35m38s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   cri          Running   OK       35m37s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   etcd         Running   Fail     35m23s ago    Health check failed: error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded
10.31.193.102   kubelet      Running   OK       35m27s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   machined     Running   OK       35m39s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   trustd       Running   OK       35m37s ago    Health check successful
10.31.193.102   udevd        Running   OK       35m38s ago    Health check successful
```

```
$ talosctl -n 10.31.193.102 -e 10.31.192.10 --talosconfig talosconfig services etcd
NODE                  10.31.193.102
ID                    etcd
STATE                 Running
HEALTH                Fail
LAST HEALTH MESSAGE   error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded
EVENTS                [Running]: Health check failed: error building etcd client: context deadline exceeded (35m43s ago)
                      [Running]: Started task etcd (PID 2389) for container etcd (35m52s ago)
                      [Preparing]: Creating service runner (35m53s ago)
                      [Preparing]: Running pre state (35m56s ago)
                      [Waiting]: Waiting for service "cri" to be "up" (35m56s ago)
                      [Waiting]: Waiting for service "cri" to be "up", time sync, network, etcd spec (35m57s ago)
```
The new control node can't be added to the cluster.

I might forget or did something wrong but i dont't know what.
### Logs
In the dmesg of the node
`10.31.193.102: user: warning: [2023-10-26T09:52:56.683171256Z]: [talos] task startAllServices (1/1): service "etcd" to be "up"`

### Environment

- Talos version: 1.3.7
- Kubernetes version: 1.25.14
- Platform: VM control plane and bare metal workers

issue.title: talosctl shutdown doesn't error if no talosconfig is passed.
issue.body:
## Bug Report

I ended up in a terminal where I hadn't exported `TALOSCONFIG` and issued a `talosctl shutdown` command and nothing happened.  I assumed it was an async command and waited... and waited.

### Description

There should be an error message if you issue a `talosctl shutdown` command without either an explicit `--talosconfig` or a `TALOSCONFIG` env var.

### Logs

```
/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
> unset TALOSCONFIG

/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
> talosctl shutdown -n 192.168.1.206 -e 192.168.1.206 --force

/home/martyn [martyn@i9worker] [22:16]
```
(no output seen on shutdown command)

### Environment

- Talos version: [`talosctl version --nodes <problematic nodes>`] 1.5.4
- Kubernetes version: [`kubectl version --short`] v1.28.2
- Platform: metal-pine64

comment.body:
you probably have a default `talosconfig` which has some (unreachable?) nodes, which `talosctl is using`.

`talosctl config info` to help, not an issue in the CLI.

issue.title: Cilium guide inlineManifests is missing being inside the cluster object
issue.body:
## Bug Report

### Description

The [Cilium guide inlineManifests](https://www.talos.dev/v1.5/kubernetes-guides/network/deploying-cilium/#method-4-helm-manifests-inline-install) is missing being inside the cluster object. It should be:

```yaml
cluster: # <--- this was missing from the guide.
  inlineManifests:
    - name: cilium
      contents: |
        --
        # Source: cilium/templates/cilium-agent/serviceaccount.yaml
        apiVersion: v1
        kind: ServiceAccount
        metadata:
          name: "cilium"
          namespace: kube-system
```
